• The invention pertains to an electro-surgical instrument used primarily for dissection and cauterization in laparoscopic/endoscopic surgeries.

column2: • It enhances visibility and safety by modifying the electrode's position relative to the insulating sleeve.

column1: • The instrument features a rigid arm that extends from the sleeve to the working tip electrode, which is laterally offset from the sleeve's axis.

column2: • This design minimizes obstruction of the surgeon's view and reduces accidental contact with healthy tissue.

column1: • Various configurations of the working tip electrode, such as hooks and spatulas, cater to different surgical needs.

column2: • These configurations are designed to improve the precision and functionality of the instrument during surgery.

column1: • The instrument includes an insulating jacket along the arm to prevent unintended cauterization of healthy tissue.

column2: • This safety feature ensures that only the working tip electrode can cauterize tissue.

column1: • The invention is adaptable for use with different electro-surgical units via a universal plug at the proximal end.

column2: • This allows for easy integration with existing surgical systems and controls.

column1: • Detailed descriptions and illustrations of the instrument's embodiments highlight specific design variations and their applications.

column2: • These details assist in understanding the practical implementation and advantages of the invention in surgical settings.

222,"<summary>
• Background and Objectives

column2: • The invention relates to a magnetic resonance imaging apparatus designed for high-contrast exposures in short times, especially for larger body segments.

column1: • Description of Prior Art

column2: • Existing MRI systems require adjustments of exposure parameters for different positions, which is time-consuming and affects image quality if skipped.

column1: • Summary of the Invention

column2: • The invention pre-determines adjustment parameters in an initial adjustment process, allowing for rapid and efficient imaging without the need for readjustment.

column1: • Key Features of the Apparatus

column2: • Includes a support plate and a patient receptacle, with options for different magnet types like cylindrical or horseshoe magnets.

column1: • Adjustment Process

column2: • Adjustment parameters are set prior to imaging, stored in memory, and reused as needed, reducing the need for repeated adjustments.

column1: • Components of the MRI System

column2: • Features transmit and receive coils, a generator, amplifiers, and a shim coil system, all controlled based on pre-set parameters.

column1: • Benefits of the Invention

column2: • Enables quicker imaging processes and maintains high image quality by avoiding the need for constant readjustments.

column1: • Potential Applications

column2: • Particularly useful in procedures like subtraction angiography or tracking contrast agent distribution in large body areas.

223,"<summary>
* The invention relates to a releasable fastener for albums like photographic albums and scrapbooks.

column2: * It allows for easy addition or replacement of pages.

column1: * The fastener includes a pair of strap anchors and a strap that passes through the album covers and pages.

column2: * Strap anchors are attached to the front and back covers.

column1: * The strap features a releasable connection with the strap anchors, allowing for adjustable length to accommodate varying album thickness.

column2: * This connection uses a snap-lock mechanism for easy adjustment.

column1: * The strap and strap anchors have interlocking formations to prevent longitudinal movement.

column2: * These formations include closely-spaced lateral ribs, possibly with a saw-tooth profile.

column1: * The strap anchors are designed with locking lips to securely hold the strap.

column2: * Multiple pairs of locking lips are used for a more secure lock.

column1: * The strap is inserted into the channel of the strap anchor through an aperture, which aligns with a hole in the cover.

column2: * This ensures correct positioning and secure attachment.

column1: * The invention simplifies the process of adding or removing pages compared to traditional screw-type fasteners.

column2: * It provides greater versatility and can be produced at a comparable cost.

column1: * The design ensures a low profile for the fasteners, allowing the album covers to close neatly without bulging.

column2: * Strap anchors and straps are concealed within the cover when closed, maintaining aesthetics and functionality.

225,"<summary>
* Background and Objectives

column2: * Relates to rotating water feeds and ventilation systems, especially for water-cooled generators.
* Addresses the issue of air bubbles in cooling systems causing inefficiency and overheating.
* Aims to provide a simple, automatic solution for removing or reducing air or gas accumulations in rotating pipes.

column1: * Description of Prior Art

column2: * Previous systems did not focus on ventilating rotating parts, leading to inefficiencies.
* Examples from historical references show lack of adequate solutions for air removal in water feeds.
* Prior solutions were often complex and not fully effective in removing air from the system.

column1: * Summary of the Invention

column2: * Introduces a bypass system between feed and discharge ducts to remove air bubbles.
* Utilizes pressure gradients for automatic operation, enhancing simplicity and effectiveness.
* Features multiple embodiments to suit different system configurations and needs.

column1: * Detailed Description of Embodiments

column2: * Various configurations include end face arrangements and radially arranged pipes.
* Some embodiments use coiled pipes or inserts with spiral grooves to increase hydrodynamic resistance.
* Each design focuses on optimizing the removal of air bubbles and improving overall system efficiency.

column1: * Advantages of the Invention

column2: * Provides a more efficient cooling system by effectively removing air bubbles.
* Simplifies the design and construction of ventilation systems in water-cooled generators.
* Offers flexibility in design to accommodate different types of water feed systems.

column1: * Illustrative Figures and Embodiments

column2: * Figures depict different structural arrangements of the bypass system.
* Descriptions explain the flow dynamics and positioning of components to maximize air removal.
* Emphasizes the practical application and versatility of the bypass system in various generator setups.

226,"<summary>
* The invention pertains to a steering column for motor vehicles designed to enhance safety during crashes.

column2: * It features a jacket unit that supports a rotatable steering shaft.
* A retaining part secures the jacket unit, allowing displacement when a force limit is exceeded.
* Includes an energy absorption connection with bending wires or strips that deform under force.
* Also incorporates a break-away connection that releases when the force limit is exceeded.

column1: * The steering column is adjustable and can be modified in length, height, or inclination to suit the driver's preference.

column2: * Adjustable features are most often implemented for driver comfort.
* Adjustments can be made in various directions including length and height.
* Known steering columns use mechanisms that allow for energy absorption during crashes.

column1: * The invention aims to reduce the force peak experienced during a crash in a simple, cost-effective manner.

column2: * Introduces an elastic prestress to bending wires or strips to lower the force needed to trigger the break-away connection.
* This modification helps in reducing the initial high force peak during a crash.
* Ensures stability during normal operations, preventing vibrations and enhancing safety.

227,"<summary>
• The application is a continuation-in-part of previous patent applications, now abandoned.

column2: ⁃ It claims all equitable rights from its predecessors.
⁃ Initial application dates back to March 30, 1987.

column1: • The invention focuses on a new method for installing glass panels in curved window bays of vehicles.

column2: ⁃ It specifically addresses using flat, uncurved glass to create curved windows.
⁃ This contrasts with the traditional use of pre-contoured and pre-stressed glass.

column1: • Current methods for installing curved glass involve expensive processes.

column2: ⁃ Glass is pre-contoured using costly annealing and tempering.
⁃ These processes make the glass less flexible and more brittle.

column1: • Disadvantages of conventional curved glass include increased brittleness and transportation issues.

column2: ⁃ Pre-contoured glass is more prone to shattering in accidents.
⁃ It also provides less structural support to vehicle bodies in crashes.

column1: • The new method aims to use flat glass, which is cheaper and more flexible.

column2: ⁃ Flat glass is less likely to shatter and can better absorb impact.
⁃ It is also significantly cheaper than pre-treated, pre-contoured glass.

column1: • The installation process involves securing the flat glass in the curved window bay and applying adhesive.

column2: ⁃ A weather sealant and adhesive compound are applied after positioning the glass.
⁃ The adhesive cures to fix the glass permanently in its curved position.

column1: • Fastening means include resilient clips and reveal molding to hold the glass.

column2: ⁃ These components help maintain the glass's curved shape during and after installation.
⁃ The reveal molding is pressed against the glass to ensure conformity to the window bay.

column1: • The invention is detailed through descriptions and drawings.

column2: ⁃ Figures illustrate both the traditional and new methods of glass installation.
⁃ Detailed views show how the glass and fastening means interact.

column1: • The method is applicable to various vehicle windows, not just rear windows.

column2: ⁃ Principles can be adapted for different types of vehicle windows.
⁃ The focus is on simplicity and cost-effectiveness.

column1: • The adhesive used is a key component, ensuring durability and flexibility.

column2: ⁃ Polysulfide adhesive is preferred for its rubber-like properties.
⁃ It withstands climate changes and stress without degradation.

* The invention focuses on a method and apparatus for removing gases from liquids, specifically designed for offshore hydrocarbon recovery platforms.

column2: * It addresses the problem of metal corrosion caused by oxygen in seawater used in oil extraction by proposing a system to efficiently remove oxygen.
* The apparatus is described as having multiple gasification chambers and uses a mechanical, cylindrical gas scavenger machine to reduce the physical profile compared to traditional stripping towers.

column1: * The detailed design and operation of the apparatus are provided, highlighting its continuous process and multi-chamber system for effective gas displacement.

column2: * The system includes a series of partitions and gas ingestion mechanisms that introduce a second gas (like nitrogen) to displace the first gas (oxygen), following Henry's Law of partial pressures.
* The design allows for the control of gas displacement and liquid flow through the apparatus, aiming to reduce oxygen levels in seawater from about 6-10 ppm to about 0.5-1.0 ppm.

229,"<summary>
• The document discusses a packaging machine with improved synchronization and compact design.

column2: • It claims priority to a European patent application and incorporates various technical improvements over prior art.

column1: • The machine includes multiple work stations with movable tool members, driven by a central shaft.

column2: • This central shaft ensures synchronized operation of the tool members across different stations.

column1: • A key feature is the use of a transfer mechanism that converts rotational movement into the required tool movements.

column2: • Examples include toggle levers and cam mechanisms, enhancing robustness and reducing wear.

column1: • The machine can operate in both continuous and intermittent modes, with possible bidirectional rotation of the shaft.

• This application is a continuation-in-part of earlier U.S. patent applications related to disposable depressed center grinding wheels with integral mounting hubs.

column2: • It builds on prior designs by enhancing the quick attachment and release mechanisms for portable power tools.

column1: • The invention addresses the problem of accidental disassociation of grinding wheels from their drive shafts, especially in quick-change scenarios.

column2: • It introduces a non-adhesive method for securing the grinding wheel to the drive shaft, improving reliability and ease of replacement.

column1: • The design includes a backing flange and a retaining nut that secure the grinding wheel without adhesives, using a pressure cap for added security.

column2: • This structure allows for increased clamping force during operation, which prevents the wheel from rotating independently of the hub.

column1: • The pressure cap is designed to engage the power tool spindle seat, placing the grinding wheel in compression during use, enhancing operational stability.

column2: • This feature ensures that the more force applied during use, the greater the compression and stability of the wheel.

column1: • The assembly is designed for ease of use, allowing for quick replacement of the grinding wheel without tools.

column2: • The spent grinding wheel and the pressure cap can be disposed of together, simplifying maintenance and reducing downtime.

column1: • The invention is applicable to various types of grinding wheels and other rotatable finishing articles like flap wheels, wire wheels, and abrasive disks.

column2: • This versatility makes it suitable for a wide range of industrial applications.

column1: • The design is optimized for smooth operation with minimal vibration, thanks to precise alignment and balanced construction.

column2: • This results in improved user comfort and efficiency during grinding operations.

column1: • The invention is lighter and less expensive than previous designs using die-cast hubs, while still meeting all known safety standards.

column2: • This makes it a cost-effective solution for industrial grinding applications.

column1: • The patent document also references a substantial number of prior art patents, indicating a thorough exploration of existing technologies and improvements over them.

column2: • This background underscores the innovative steps taken in the development of the new grinding wheel assembly.

* The invention relates to a hydraulic unit for vehicle brake systems, improving on prior designs by preventing pressure fluid from impairing electrical components.

column2: * It features a design where pressure fluid entrained into a cam element chamber is collected in a spring chamber, away from electrical components.
* This design eliminates the need for certain elements like check valves and permeable elements at venting points, leading to cost savings and a hermetic seal against environmental exposure.

column1: * The hydraulic unit includes a motor, eccentric chamber, and various conduits for managing pressure fluid and air pressure.

column2: * Conduits are designed to divert pressure fluid away from electrical components and towards spring chambers where it can be safely collected.
* Pressure equalization between the motor, spring chambers, and the ambient atmosphere is managed through specific conduit designs, enhancing the unit's reliability and functionality.

column1: * The document details multiple exemplary embodiments of the hydraulic unit, each illustrating different aspects and improvements.

column2: * The first exemplary embodiment describes the basic setup and function of the hydraulic unit components and their interaction.
* Subsequent embodiments introduce variations like different conduit arrangements and motor configurations to optimize performance and manufacturing costs.

column2: **Claim of Priority and Related Art**

column3: Priority based on Provisional Application Serial No. 60/042,080 filed on March 28, 1997.
Discusses prior art rail car truck bowl liners including metal alloys, ultra high molecular weight polymers, and hybrid composites.
Identifies issues with non-conductive liners requiring separate grounding apparatus.

column2: **Summary of the Invention**

column3: Describes a grounding product for railroad car center plate assembly bowl liners made from all polymeric materials.
Aims to provide effective grounding without conductive plates, clips, or shunts.
References improvements over prior patents, enhancing electrical properties while maintaining mechanical characteristics.

column2: **Detailed Description of Preferred Embodiment**

column3: Explains the use of a liner composed of ultra high molecular weight polyethylene (UHMW-PE) mixed with 2% carbon black.
Highlights the benefits of the liner in terms of self-lubrication and enhanced conductivity.
Details the structural and functional aspects of the liner in various configurations.

column2: **Technical Advantages**

column3: Enhanced conductivity meets and exceeds industry standards for static electricity conductivity.
Self-lubricating properties reduce the need for maintenance and improve durability.
Conductive material distribution within the liner ensures consistent performance even under varying loads.

column2: **Drawings and Embodiments**

column3: Includes several figures illustrating the liner in different configurations and its placement in the truck assembly.
Shows both full bowl and flat horizontal disk embodiments.
Describes alternative embodiments with varying concentrations of conductive material.

column2: **Potential Improvements and Variations**

column3: Discusses the possibility of using other polymers and varying the carbon black content.
Considers the impact of load on conductivity, with higher loads potentially improving conductivity.
Suggests that wear and polishing of the liner could expose more conductive particles, maintaining effectiveness over time.

column2: The patent application discusses a vehicular rearview mirror system that adapts to different vehicle control output protocols, particularly focusing on the reverse-gear indication.

column3: The system includes an electro-optic reflective element that adjusts its reflectance level based on the vehicle's gear status.
A mirror control circuit uses inputs from vehicle controls to adjust mirror settings and can determine the protocol of these inputs.
The system is designed to be universally compatible with various vehicle protocols without needing hardware modifications.
Examples of vehicle control outputs include gear status, engine information, alarm information, and door status information.

column2: The application details a software-based method to determine and adapt to the vehicle control's output protocol, enhancing the rearview mirror system's functionality.

column3: The mirror controller, possibly a microcomputer, adjusts the mirror based on data like light levels and reverse gear engagement.
The system's software logic includes routines to handle power-up sequences and ongoing operation to maintain accurate protocol detection.
Protocols can vary, such as indicating reverse gear by changing from low to high voltage or vice versa.
The system's adaptability is achieved through software, minimizing additional hardware costs and utilizing existing microcomputers in mirror systems.

* The invention relates to an anti-lock braking system for motorcycles, specifically designed to address issues of front wheel lock and chassis vibration during braking.

column2: * Incorporates a master cylinder, front wheel brakes, and an anti-lock control unit to manage hydraulic pressure and prevent wheel lock.
* Employs a damped telescopic front suspension with an anti-dive device that responds to brake force, enhancing stability and braking efficiency.
* Described system improvements are detailed through various embodiments, showing modifications in hydraulic control and fork design to optimize performance.

column1: * The detailed embodiments explain the mechanical and hydraulic components of the system, demonstrating how they interact to prevent front wheel lock and manage fork dive.

column2: * Includes a hydraulic pump, modulator, and pressure discharge valve integrated within the wheel hub to regulate brake pressure dynamically.
* Features an anti-dive unit that adjusts the telescopic front fork's response to braking force, minimizing fork compression and enhancing tire contact with the road.
* Utilizes sensors and a display circuit to monitor system performance and provide feedback on the anti-lock and anti-dive functions, ensuring optimal operation.

* Cross-Reference and Technical Field

column2: * Application is a continuation of a provisional patent application filed on Jul. 20, 2000.
* Relates to movable partitions and panels for cargo separation or insulation during transport or storage.
* Particularly useful in multi-temperature transport for perishable items.
* Addresses the need for efficient space utilization and temperature control in cargo areas.

column1: * Background Information

column2: * Perishable items are transported in refrigerated trailers, railcars, or containers.
* Refrigeration units maintain desired temperatures and humidities.
* Existing systems typically cool entire cargo spaces, which can be inefficient and costly.
* Movable partitions and bulkheads allow for the division of cargo spaces into smaller, separately controlled environments.

column1: * Summary of the Invention

column2: * Improved partition system with at least two independently movable panels.
* Panels are attached to ceiling-mounted rails in a refrigerated trailer.
* Allows for the creation of multiple cargo areas with different temperatures.
* Includes a removable center partition wall for additional configuration flexibility.

column1: * Brief Description of the Drawings

column2: * FIG. 1 shows a trailer with center partition panels and a rail and trolley system.
* FIG. 2 provides a plan view of the rail system.
* FIG. 3 and FIG. 4 depict the mechanism for moving and stowing the panels.
* FIG. 5 illustrates a detailed view of a lift mechanism used in the system.

column1: * Detailed Description of Preferred Embodiments

column2: * Describes various configurations and functionalities of the panel, trolley assembly, and rail system.
* Panels can be moved, raised, and secured in different positions within the trailer.
* Modifications can be made to adapt the system to different trailer designs or requirements.
* Emphasizes the flexibility and efficiency of the system in managing cargo space and temperature control.

column1: * Additional Features and Modifications

column2: * Panels can be used without center partitions to form a full-width horizontal bulkhead.
* Each panel is independently and slidably mounted, allowing for easy adjustment and stowing.
* Various securing means can be used to fasten panels together or to the trailer structure.
* The system is designed to reduce the clearance needed for panel adjustment and stowing, enhancing usability in tight spaces.

238,"<summary>
• Background and Need for Innovation:
• Discusses the use of rotary valves in fluid handling and liquid chromatography, specifically for the pharmaceutical industry.
• Highlights the limitations of existing rotary valves which require disassembly for cleaning and lack sanitizable features.
• Emphasizes the need for a novel sanitizable rotary valve that can be cleaned without disassembly to maintain sterile conditions.
• References prior art and existing patents that lack the necessary features for effective sanitization in pharmaceutical applications.
• Description of the New Invention:
• Introduces a novel rotary valve design that allows for sanitization without disassembly.
• Features a unique diaphragm-like elastomeric seal that enables both sealing during normal operation and retention of sanitizing fluids during cleaning.
• Incorporates a rotary carousel diaphragm valve with thermoplastic elastomeric diaphragm molded to form multiple sealing ports.
• Allows for orthogonal movement of the rotor away from the stator to facilitate cross flushing of the port sealing faces.
• Technical Details and Operation:
• Describes the specific construction of the rotor and stator, including the integration of the elastomeric diaphragm.
• Outlines the process of insert molding for forming the rotary valve diaphragm seal.
• Explains the operation of the valve, including the movement and indexing of ports for fluid handling.
• Details the sanitization process, which involves partial separation of the rotor and stator for flushing with sanitizing fluid.
• Advantages of the Invention:
• Provides a sanitizable design that maintains the sterile condition of the system, crucial for pharmaceutical manufacturing.
• Reduces the risk of contamination and increases the reliability of the separation process.
• Offers a design that is less prone to damage and wear, extending the operational life of the valve.
• Facilitates easier and more efficient maintenance compared to traditional valves.
• Applications and Implications:
• Primarily aimed at improving processes in the pharmaceutical industry, particularly in the separation and purification of biological macromolecules.
• Can be integrated into existing systems to enhance the efficiency and safety of fluid handling and chromatographic separation.
• Potential to set new standards for valve design in terms of hygiene, maintenance, and operational efficiency.
• Opens avenues for further innovation in valve technologies and their applications in various industries.

column2: * Relates to gas-liquid contacting trays in distillation columns.

column1: * Prior Art and Developments

column1: * Details of the Improved Tray Valve Assembly

column1: * Operational and Structural Advantages

* The invention pertains to a fluid pressure regulator assembly designed to generate power while regulating fluid pressure.

column2: * It addresses the energy loss in traditional fluid pressure regulators.

column1: * The assembly includes a vane motor for converting pressurized fluid into mechanical power.

column2: * The vane motor is connected to a fluid source and a fluid regulator.

column1: * The invention provides several advantages over prior art.

column2: * It reduces the size and cost of the fluid regulator needed.

column1: * The detailed description includes specific embodiments and components.

column1: * The invention is applicable in various fields.

* The invention pertains to an advanced pallet system designed to enhance the stability and handling of loaded items, particularly trays.

column2: * The system includes a pallet with raised parallel guide rails that accommodate the side supports of trays, limiting lateral movement.
* End stops and end plates are incorporated to restrict longitudinal movement and add rigidity to the loaded trays.

column1: * The pallet system can be configured with a pallet cap that fits onto a conventional pallet base, or as a single integrated unit.

column2: * The pallet cap has pockets that align with and fit into the pockets of the base pallet, ensuring stability and proper positioning.

column2: The invention relates to streptavidin muteins with enhanced binding affinity for peptide ligands.
• These muteins are produced using recombinant DNA technology.
• They are used for isolating, purifying, and determining biological substances, especially recombinant proteins.
Streptavidin muteins are characterized by mutations in specific amino acid positions, improving their binding strength compared to wild-type streptavidin.
• Mutations are particularly focused in the amino acid positions 44 to 53.
• Preferred muteins include substitutions that increase affinity for peptide ligands used in various detection and purification methods.
The invention also covers methods for producing and using these muteins in practical applications.
• Techniques include affinity chromatography and ELISA for detecting and purifying tagged proteins.
• The muteins can be used in both traditional streptavidin/biotin systems and novel peptide ligand systems for enhanced performance.

244,"<summary>
• Overview of the Invention:
• Focuses on methods to form substituted guanidines using nickel catalysts.
• Utilizes guanylating agents like thioureas or isothioureas.
• Nickel catalysts are preferred in the zero oxidation state.
• Nickel catalysts include those derived from nickel-boride alloys, nickel-phosphide alloys, and others.
• Importance of Guanidine Functional Group:
• Integral in many biologically active compounds.
• Strongly basic, often fully protonated under physiological conditions.
• Found in drugs like anti-ulcer and cardiovascular medications.
• Synthetic methods aim for mild conditions and high yields to minimize costs and by-products.
• Prior Art and Disadvantages:
• Traditional synthesis involves excess reagents and longer reaction times.
• Commonly used toxic mercuric salts pose separation and toxicity challenges.
• Reversible reactions with certain agents like N-alkyl substituted S-methylisothioureas complicate synthesis.
• Innovations in the Invention:
• Nickel catalysts reduce the need for large quantities of reagents.
• Catalysts are recoverable and reusable, enhancing cost-effectiveness.
• Preferred guanylating agents are thioureas and isothioureas with specific protective groups.
• Reaction conditions are optimized for room temperature, improving safety and efficiency.
• Detailed Examples and Reaction Conditions:
• Examples illustrate the synthesis of various guanidines using nickel catalysts.
• Reactions are performed under controlled temperatures with specific amines and thioureas.
• Various nickel catalysts are tested for effectiveness and speed.
• Results demonstrate high yields and the potential for reduced reaction times with specific catalysts.

245,"<summary>
* The invention pertains to a novel apparatus and method for continuously electrolytic coloring of aluminum strips or wires.

column2: * This includes a first anodic oxidation followed by electrolytic coloration.

column1: * The prior art methods had limitations such as poor weatherability and high energy consumption.

column2: * Conventional methods also risked cracking the oxide film during continuous processing.

column1: * The invention builds on a previously discovered method that uses specific acids or water-soluble metal salts for electrolytic coloring.

column2: * This method improves the weatherability and fade resistance of the colored aluminum.

column1: * The apparatus includes a series of baths and a power source setup that allows the aluminum strip or wire to function as an anode and then as a cathode.

column2: * This setup avoids the need to directly connect the aluminum strip or wire to the power source.

column1: * The anodic oxidation bath typically uses a sulfuric acid solution, which can be adjusted with additives to affect the film properties.

column2: * Desired oxide film thickness for effective coloring is between 4 to 15 microns.

column1: * The electrolytic coloring bath contains metal salts or selenious acid, which can achieve various colors under controlled conditions.

column2: * Colors range from yellow-brown to black depending on the components and electrolytic conditions.

column1: * The process includes a degreasing bath, an etching bath, and a sealing bath to finish the treatment of the aluminum.

column2: * These pre and post treatments ensure cleanliness and durability of the colored aluminum.

column1: * The apparatus is designed for continuous operation, which is beneficial for industrial scale production.

column2: * It includes mechanisms for controlling electric current and bath compositions.

column1: * Modifications and variations of the apparatus can be made without departing from the scope of the invention.

column2: * This flexibility allows adaptation to different industrial needs and improvements.

column1: * The invention offers significant improvements over previous methods, including reduced energy requirements and enhanced product qualities.

column2: * This makes it particularly valuable for producing building materials and other applications requiring durable colored aluminum.

* The invention focuses on methods for producing transgenic plants:

column2: * Involves transforming plants on a chromosome with specific DNA sequences.
* Includes screening nucleotide sequences to identify desired plant phenotypes.
* Produces transgenic plants and libraries of plants or seeds using these methods.
* Utilizes vectors adapted for these processes in plant or plant cell transformation.

column1: * Background and existing methods:

column2: * Current stable plant transformation methods use direct methods like microprojectile bombardment or Agrobacterium-mediated DNA delivery.
* Techniques focus on integrating pre-engineered DNA fragments into plant cells.
* Existing methods aim to simplify complex DNA integration patterns and remove auxiliary DNA sequences.

column1: * Objectives of the invention:

column2: * Enhance efficiency, versatility, and speed of transforming plants on a chromosome.
* Enable in planta engineering of DNA sequences for integration, including those toxic to bacteria.
* Allow modular use of vectors to reduce cloning work and vector size.
* Facilitate screening of DNA libraries for desired functions directly in plants.

column1: * Detailed process and applications:

column2: * Involves providing plant cells with multiple vectors that recombine to produce a desired DNA sequence.
* The process includes selecting plants expressing the desired traits from these transformations.
* Applications include DNA library screening, gene function analysis, and directed evolution.
* The method can assemble complex DNA sequences in planta from smaller precursors, enhancing genetic diversity and experimentation.

247,"<summary>
* Background and Field of the Invention

column2: * Relates to swash plate type compressors used in automotive air conditioning.
* Focuses on reducing frictional wear by applying a fluorocarbon coating.
* Aims to use lower cost alloy materials while maintaining durability.
* Enhances efficiency by improving the compressor's component lifespan.

column1: * Description of the Related Art

column2: * Swash plate compressors have a high surface area that contacts piston shoes, causing friction.
* Previous solutions included metal matrix coatings with elements like tin and silicon.
* Fluororesin was added to coatings to reduce friction but compromised hardness.
* High silicon aluminum and tin coatings increased durability but not without drawbacks.

column1: * Summary of the Invention

column2: * Introduces a heat curable, cross-linked polyfluoro elastomer coating.
* Coating includes lubricious and load bearing additives.
* Applied via aqueous spray and cured at elevated temperatures.
* Allows the use of lower cost, low silicon aluminum materials.

column1: * Detailed Description of Preferred Embodiments

column2: * Explains the compressor structure and the interaction between swash plate and pistons.
* Describes the application process of the polyfluoro elastomer coating.
* Details the preferred roughness and thickness for effective coating adhesion and performance.
* Specifies preferred materials and mix ratios for the coating composition.

column1: * Experimental Results and Advantages

column2: * Demonstrates significant improvements in durability and friction coefficient.
* Coated plates outperform uncoated and traditionally coated counterparts under stress tests.
* Allows for reduced manufacturing complexity and costs by eliminating steps like high polish.
* Provides a durable, low-friction solution adaptable to various aluminum silicon percentages.

* The polymers can be combined with light-absorbing compounds to form effective anti-reflective coatings.

* Anti-reflective coatings are applied to semiconductor wafers, followed by hard-baking to form a cross-linked structure.

250,"<summary>
• Field and Background of the Invention

column2: • Focuses on a method for producing 1,1,1-trifluoroethane (143a) via continuous gas phase hydrofluorination.
• Uses 1,1-difluoro-1-chloroethane (142b) and heterogeneous catalysis.
• Addresses the need for an economical and efficient industrial process.
• Previous methods involved undesirable by-products and inefficient catalysts.

column1: • Details of Previous Techniques and Patents

column2: • Various patents describe different catalysts and processes with varying efficiency and selectivity.
• Issues included high toxicity of reagents, long catalyst regeneration times, and low conversion rates.
• Some processes used expensive or corrosive materials, impacting practical industrial application.
• Prior methods often produced significant amounts of unwanted by-products.

column1: • Novelty of the Current Invention

column2: • Achieves over 99% conversion and selectivity for 143a.
• Minimizes the formation of olefinic by-products.
• Utilizes a Cr catalyst which may be unsupported or supported, potentially with nickel, cobalt, or manganese salts.
• Demonstrates unexpected high efficiency given the simplicity of the catalysts used.

column1: • Catalysts and Conditions Explored

column2: • Various catalysts tested including CrF3.4H2O and Cr/Ni/AlF3, showing high performance.
• Conditions such as temperature, HF:142b molar ratio, and contact time were optimized.
• High temperature and incorrect molar ratios previously led to lower selectivity and unwanted by-products.
• Catalyst regeneration methods were also explored to maintain efficiency.

column1: • Process Description and Reactor Details

column2: • Describes a preferred reactor setup for the hydrofluorination process.
• Outlines methods for removing by-products like HCl and unreacted HF.
• Discusses the potential for using different feed compositions including impure streams.
• Emphasizes the importance of maintaining specific reaction conditions for optimal results.

column1: • Experimental Results and Observations

column2: • Provides detailed experimental setups and results demonstrating the process's effectiveness.
• Highlights the stability and longevity of the catalysts under prolonged operational periods.
• Confirms the necessity of catalysts for achieving high conversion rates.
• Shows that the process can handle various operational pressures and temperatures efficiently.

column1: • Implications and Advantages of the Invention

column2: • Offers a more sustainable and less toxic method for producing 143a",0

column2: ⁃ Hypophosphorous acid is used in the deacylation and desulfurization steps, enhancing yield and purity.
⁃ The process reduces the formation of sulfur and sulfur-containing organic impurities compared to methods without hypophosphorous acid.

column1: • Background and challenges of existing methods are discussed.

column2: ⁃ Previous methods involved complex steps and produced significant impurities, including sulfur and sulfur derivatives.
⁃ These impurities could interfere with further reactions and degrade the quality of photographic products.

column1: • Advantages of using hypophosphorous acid in the synthesis process are highlighted.

column2: ⁃ It minimizes the production of undesirable by-products and increases the yield of the desired product.
⁃ Hypophosphorous acid helps in forming H2S, which is easier to remove from the reaction zone compared to solid sulfur.

column1: • Description of preferred embodiments and detailed process steps.

column2: ⁃ The process involves reacting an acylated compound with a mixture of hypophosphorous acid and hydrochloric or hydrobromic acid.
⁃ Conditions such as temperature, pressure, and reaction time are optimized to achieve high purity and yield.

column1: • Examples demonstrate the practical application and effectiveness of the improved process.

column2: ⁃ Example 1 details the synthesis of a specific pyrazolotriazole with an 82% yield and 98% purity.
⁃ Subsequent examples outline variations and confirm the reproducibility and scalability of the process.

column1: • The invention is adaptable for industrial use due to its straightforward, economical approach.

column2: ⁃ It overcomes significant challenges associated with previous methods.
⁃ The process is designed to be environmentally friendly by reducing hazardous by-product formation.

* Background and Issues with Previous Methods

column2: * Relates to forming fiber mixtures from different fiber types.
* Previous methods involved sequential removal from fiber bales, leading to non-optimal mixtures.
* Disadvantages included residual fibers and non-uniform fiber removal.
* Required additional labor and expense due to these inefficiencies.

column1: * Objectives of the Invention

column2: * Improve the method to eliminate residuals and achieve homogeneous mixtures.
* Ensure all fiber bales are opened without leaving fiber quantities.
* Allow for continuous and accurate removal of fiber quantities.

column1: * Key Innovations Introduced

column2: * Measurement of entire fiber quantity before each pass.
* Calculation and removal of a precise partial quantity from each bale.
* Continuous adjustment and correction of fiber quantity removed in each pass.

column1: * Apparatus Components

column2: * Includes a bale opener, quantity measuring device, and a control device.
* Quantity measuring could be a height-measuring arrangement or other sensors.
* Control device adjusts the bale opener based on real-time measurements.

column1: * Operational Enhancements

column2: * Ensures timely removal of fibers to match processing machine speeds.
* Can accelerate fiber removal to meet predetermined time schedules.
* Reduces delays and prevents idle runs of connected processing machines.

column1: * Examples and Implementation

column2: * Detailed examples show the method applied to different fiber bales.
* Demonstrates how adjustments are made based on real-time data.
* Illustrates the benefits of the new method in terms of efficiency and fiber mixture quality.

• Overview of the Invention:

column2: • Focuses on methods and apparatus for creating bias laid, non-woven fabrics.
• Yarns in the fabric are laid at angles between 30° and 150° to the fabric's long axis.
• Fabrics are held together by stitching, knitting, or adhesive bonding until resin impregnation.

column1: • Prior Art and Innovations:

column2: • Traditional fabrics lack the strength needed for modern structural applications like airplane parts.
• Previous patents and methods, such as those by Campman et al, are discussed and differentiated.
• The invention improves on existing methods by enabling parallel yarn courses and reducing material waste.

column1: • Detailed Mechanism Description:

column2: • Utilizes a rake mechanism that works in conjunction with conveyors and yarn carriers.
• Rake needles and conveyor needles interact to lay yarns precisely and maintain parallelism.
• The rake system can move yarns in a controlled overlap for increased fabric density.

column1: • Fabric Formation Process:

column2: • Yarn carriers move across conveyors, laying yarns at predetermined angles.
• Yarns are either placed between needles or impaled on them, depending on the setup.
• Movement of the rake system is crucial for positioning yarns correctly on the conveyors.

column1: • Bonding and Finalizing Fabric:

column2: • Various bonding methods like stitching, knitting, or adhesive application are used to secure the fabric layers.
• The invention can utilize existing industrial machines like the Liba Copcentra-HS for stitching.
• After bonding, excess loops formed during the yarn laying process can be trimmed off.

column1: • Applications and Advantages:

column2: • Primarily used for creating structural parts in aerospace and similar industries.
• Offers improved strength, uniformity, and efficient use of materials.
• Allows for customization of fabric density and layering based on end-use requirements.

* Background and Objectives

column2: * Relates to buttonhole controlling devices for sewing machines.
* Addresses issues with existing devices that struggle with different fabric types.
* Aims to provide a device that ensures buttonhole stitching closes without overlap.
* Seeks to improve the precision of buttonhole formation across various materials.

column1: * Description of the Invention

column2: * Includes a foot pad attached to a presser bar and a traveling assembly.
* Features a slidable member positioned by a button to define buttonhole length.
* Utilizes a tripping lever actuated by the traveling assembly to control stitching.

column1: * Operational Details

column2: * The device controls the sewing machine's tripping lever via flexible contacts.
* Initial and final positions of the traveling assembly are defined by springs.
* The device is adaptable to different button sizes and fabric types.

column1: * Description of the Drawings

* Provides guidance on adjusting the device for different materials and button sizes.

column1: * Practical Application

column2: * Allows operators to sew neat buttonholes consistently on various fabrics.
* Offers the ability to test and adjust settings using a sample material before final sewing.
* Enhances the flexibility and utility of sewing machines equipped with this device.

column1: * Modifications and Claims

* The document describes a continuation of a previously abandoned patent application.

column2: * Original application Ser. No. 919,223 filed on October 15, 1986.
* Focuses on an apparatus for treating textile webs with liquids.
* Specifically addresses issues with previous methods in handling delicate fabrics like knitted materials.

column1: * Background technologies are discussed, highlighting their limitations.

column2: * German Patent No. 830 040 introduces a method using successive spray and suction.
* German Patent Document No. 23 62 109 uses an endless sieve belt for liquid application and removal.
* German Petty Patent No. 17 40 815 describes a boot-like washing chamber, unsuitable for printed or delicate textiles.

column1: * The invention aims to improve fabric treatment apparatuses.

column2: * Enhances the washing or rinsing process without stacking the fabric.
* Reduces the tension applied to the textile web during treatment.
* Suitable for printed materials, preventing smudging and soiling.

column1: * The apparatus includes several key components.

column2: * A conveyor with an endless sieve belt.
* A liquid applicator and a suction device positioned along the belt.
* A dwell stretch that allows the fabric to relax and expose more surface area to the treatment.

column1: * Innovative features of the dwell stretch are detailed.

column2: * Can be an air pass with freely rotatable rollers or a drum with adjacent rollers.
* Allows the fabric to be free of support, enhancing treatment effectiveness.
* Designed to handle less resistant materials gently.

column1: * The apparatus offers a compact and efficient design.

column2: * Textile web returns to the sieve belt close to the suction device.
* Ensures minimal tension and effective entrainment of the web through the treatment process.
* Multiple assembly units can be included for sequential treatments.

column1: * Drawings illustrate two embodiments of the apparatus.

column2: * FIG. 1 shows a side view with air passes forming vertical loops.
* FIG. 2 depicts an alternative setup with a sieve drum and guide rollers.
* Both designs aim to optimize the treatment process and fabric handling.

column1: * Potential applications and benefits of the invention are discussed.

column2: * Particularly useful for ""soilage washing"" of heavily soiled fabrics.
* Can be followed by a fastness treatment for further processing.
* Offers significant improvements over traditional stacked or tension-heavy methods.

260,"<summary>

column2: Cross Reference and Background:

column3: This document is a division of a previously filed application from 1974, now a U.S. Patent.
It shares common matter with other co-pending applications of the same assignee.
The invention relates to an air flow system in dry cleaners to minimize toxic solvent vapor escape.
Previously, air flow systems also exhausted solvent vapors, which is economically disadvantageous with expensive solvents.

column2: Summary of the Invention:

column3: The invention provides a separate air intake system to reduce solvent vapor loss when the machine door is opened.
It includes a separate intake fan and duct with a normally closed valve that isolates the intake from solvent vapors during normal operations.
The system activates when the door opens, drawing ambient air directly into the duct, minimizing solvent vapor loss.
The design retains most of the solvent vapors within the tubs, reducing economic losses.

column2: Description of Drawings:

column3: Four figures illustrate the solvent and air distributing systems, and machine controls.
Figures show schematic views of the dry cleaner's internal and external components.
A timer cycle chart and a wiring diagram are included to explain operational timing and control logic.
The drawings detail both the placement and function of various components like tubs, fans, and filters.

column2: Preferred Embodiment:

column3: The dry cleaner includes nested tubs, solvent pumps, and a blower for air circulation.
Operational cycles include washing, spinning, and drying with solvent and air flow management.
Solvent flow systems and air flow systems are described through various cycle phases.
Special mechanisms like diverter valves and one-way valves control the flow and direction of solvents and air.

column2: Solvent and Air Flow Systems:

column3: Detailed descriptions of solvent flow paths during different operational phases.
Air flow system designed to prevent solvent vapor loss and protect against uneven drying of clothes.
Includes safety features like pressure release valves and solvent vapor recovery systems.
Explains the interaction between air flow and solvent systems to optimize cleaning and drying efficiency.

column2: Refrigeration and Vapor Handling:

column3: A refrigeration system helps condense solvent vapors and maintain solvent temperature.
Solvent vapors are managed to prevent pressure buildup",0

• Overview of the Sewing Machine Technology:

column2: • Claims priority to a Japanese Patent Application from 2012.
• Relates to a sewing machine, an embroidery unit, and a control program.
• Enhances the ease of setting sewing positions on a work cloth.
• Incorporates ultrasonic detection for position setting.

column1: • Problems with Previous Technology:

column2: • Required physical markers to be affixed to the cloth.
• Markers had to be removed before sewing, complicating the process.
• Relied on imaging systems to determine the position and angle for embroidery.

column1: • Innovations in the Current Disclosure:

column2: • Utilizes ultrasonic waves to detect the position without physical markers.
• Includes a memory storing instructions for ultrasonic wave-based control.
• Embroidery unit can be attached/detached and moves based on ultrasonic detection.
• Notifies the sewing machine of the detection timing for precise control.

column1: • Detailed Description of the Embroidery Unit:

column2: • Can move an embroidery frame holding the work cloth.
• Detects ultrasonic waves from a transmission source.
• Notifies the sewing machine about the detection timing.
• Moves the work cloth based on the identified position of the transmission source.

column1: • Non-Transitory Computer-Readable Medium:

column2: • Stores a control program executable on a sewing machine.
• Program includes instructions for identifying the position of the ultrasonic transmission source.
• Controls sewing based on the identified position.

column1: • Advantages of the New System:

column2: • Eliminates the need for physical markers, simplifying the sewing preparation.
• Allows for easy and accurate setting of sewing positions.
• Enhances user convenience and efficiency in sewing operations.

column1: • Potential for Future Applications:

column2: • Could be expanded to other forms of fabric manipulation machines.
• Offers a framework for further automation in textile processing.
• May integrate with other digital tools for enhanced design precision.

263,"<summary>

column2: The invention pertains to enhancing the utility of cellulosic fabrics using specific preparations.

column3: These preparations include wool particles or powder and bamboo fiber as carriers for functional additives.
The additives aim to improve properties such as UV protection, anti-bacterial effects, and moisture management.
The preparations are applied to fabrics like cotton and linen to enhance durability and functionality.

column2: Methods of preparing these fabric treatments involve pulverizing materials into ultrafine powders.

column3: Wool and bamboo fibers are processed into powders and then formed into suspensions.
Functional additives like zinc oxide and titanium dioxide are incorporated into these suspensions.
The resulting preparations are applied to fabrics using methods like printing, padding, or foam application.

column2: The invention utilizes environmentally friendly materials and processes.

column3: Recycles wool fibers that are too short for yarn production, using them as carriers for functional additives.
Uses bamboo powder, which provides good moisture management and is sustainable.
The processes are designed to minimize waste and utilize natural resources efficiently.

column2: Significant improvements in fabric properties are documented.

column3: Fabrics treated with these preparations show enhanced UV protection, even after multiple washes.
Improved moisture wicking and quick drying properties are achieved.
Wrinkle recovery and anti-bacterial properties are also enhanced.

column2: Testing and validation of the fabric treatments show promising results.

column3: UV protection levels are maintained through multiple wash cycles, demonstrating durability.
Wicking tests confirm better moisture management compared to untreated fabrics.
Wrinkle recovery and anti-bacterial effectiveness are quantitatively improved, confirming the functional benefits of the treatments.

• Overview of the Invention:

column2: • Relates to frame quilting machines used for sewing patterns into large textiles like bedspreads and quilts.

column1: • Prior Art and Innovations:

column2: • Existing industrial sewing operations use a single computer to control both stitching and frame table movements.

265,"<summary>
* Overview of the Invention

column2: * Relates to methods of making nonwoven fabrics.
* Focuses on a two-sided nonwoven fabric with a three-dimensional image.
* Suitable for various consumer applications.
* Enhances both aesthetic and functional properties of the fabric.

column1: * Background and Existing Technologies

column2: * Traditional fabric making involves complex, multi-step processes.
* Nonwoven fabrics are generally more efficient to produce than woven fabrics.
* Existing nonwoven fabrics often lack in terms of durability and resistance to elongation.
* Hydroentanglement and use of support layers (scrim) have improved fabric properties.

column1: * Technical Details of the Invention

column2: * Incorporates a fluid-pervious support layer or scrim between two fibrous matrices.
* Utilizes hydroentanglement on a moveable imaging surface for three-dimensional imaging.
* Aims to produce a fabric with pronounced images and necessary mechanical characteristics.
* Offers enhanced durability and resistance to delamination.

column1: * Specific Embodiments and Variations

column2: * Different fibrous matrices can be used on each side of the fabric.
* The fabric can include apertures and vary in fiber modulus.
* The fibrous matrix in contact with the imaging device is typically of lower modulus.
* Various post-entanglement treatments can be applied to enhance fabric properties.

column1: * Applications and Advantages

column2: * Suitable for home, medical, and hygiene applications.
* Offers improved loop durability and resistance to fuzz.
* Can be used in products like diapers, wipes, medical gauze, and protective wear.
* Provides economic advantages due to efficient manufacturing.

column1: * Manufacturing Process

column2: * Involves carding and cross-lapping fibers to form precursor webs.
* Hydroentanglement techniques are used to integrate and image the fabric.
* Support layers are incorporated to control fiber distribution and enhance performance.
* Optional treatments post-entanglement can include applying binders or surfactants.

266,"<summary>
* The invention pertains to a sewing machine designed for feeding and sewing strips of material into cuts of fabric.

column2: * It improves upon prior art by enabling continuous operation and handling of stiff materials without damaging the sewing needle.

column1: * The device features a control mechanism that uses a movable stop in the strip's feed path, which is actuated by the material itself.

column2: * This stop is retracted after contact, allowing the sewing process to commence without manual intervention.

column1: * The stop mechanism is part of a control setup that includes a two-armed lever and a signal transmitter, which together control the sewing machine's operations based on the strip's position.

column2: * Adjustments to the stop's position are facilitated by an air cylinder and adjustable stops.

column1: * The invention aims to simplify the sewing process for adding strips to fabric, such as in automotive seat covers, by automating the placement and initiation of sewing.

column2: * This is achieved through a sequence of controlled operations that ensure the material is correctly positioned and secured before sewing.

column1: * The device includes a guide apparatus for the strip material and various control elements like proximity switches and solenoid valves to manage the sewing operation.

column2: * These components work together to ensure the strip is fed into the correct position relative to the fabric cut before sewing.

column1: * The system is designed to be robust and economical, with features that prevent needle damage and ensure precise operation even with tough materials.

column2: * The design also allows for easy adjustment and maintenance, enhancing the machine's usability and reliability.

column1: * A detailed description of the preferred embodiment outlines the specific arrangement of mechanical parts and their interaction during the sewing process.

column2: * This includes descriptions of the mounting plate, air cylinders, control levers, and the sequence of operations for handling the strip material and fabric.

267,"<summary>

* The invention addresses issues in traditional methods of attaching tape-shaped knit parts to garments, which often result in increased thickness and discomfort, as well as higher production costs due to separate sewing processes.

column2: * Manual linking methods also lead to inconsistencies that can lower product value.

column1: * The proposed method involves a connective knitting technique using a flat knitting machine with movable needle beds to seamlessly join two tape-shaped knit pieces.

column2: * This method integrates the joining process into the knitting procedure, enhancing productivity and reducing manufacturing costs.

column1: * The knitting machine setup includes at least a pair of front and rear needle beds, with at least one being movable longitudinally.

column2: * Two tape-shaped knit pieces are knitted side by side on these beds until they reach a specified length.

column1: * The joining process involves overlaying and binding off symmetrical loops from the final courses of both knit pieces, gradually reducing the number of loops until the pieces are connected.

column2: * This is achieved by transferring loops between the needle beds and forming new loops on overlaid parts.

column1: * Detailed steps of the knitting and joining process are illustrated in the provided diagrams (FIGS. 1A-1F), showing the movement of loops and needle beds.

column2: * These steps ensure a secure and aesthetically pleasing join without increasing the fabric's thickness.

column1: * The method is versatile and can be applied to various garment parts such as sweater collars, tank top neck ropes, and apron neck ropes.

column2: * It can also be adapted to different knitting textures like plain, rib, or tubular knitting.

column1: * The technology allows for automated control via a computer that follows a pre-designed knitting pattern, ensuring consistency and precision in the knitting process.

column2: * This automation reduces the likelihood of human error and variability in the product quality.

column1: * The invention can be implemented with different configurations of the knitting machine, whether it's the rear needle bed, the front needle bed, or both that are movable.

column2: * This flexibility allows for customization according to specific production needs and garment designs.

column1: * The method not only improves the structural integrity and finish of the knit fabric connections but also enhances the overall comfort and appearance of the final garment.

column2: * By integrating the joining of knit pieces into the knitting process, the invention streamlines production and reduces the need for post-knitting adjustments.

column1: * The described embodiment and method provide a significant improvement over traditional sewing and linking techniques, offering a more efficient and scalable solution for high-quality knitwear production.

column2: * This innovation has the potential to transform practices in the knitwear industry",1

column1: 268,"<summary>
* Background and Objectives of the Invention

column2: * Relates to a flexible traction element for lifts, made of stranded cables sheathed in thermoplastic material.
* Aims to increase flexibility and improve long-term adhesion between cables and jacket.
* Seeks to precisely control cable spacing from the band surfaces at high production speeds.

column1: * Description of Related Art

column2: * U.S. Pat. No. 3,348,585 discusses rubber bands with embedded ferromagnetic strands for industrial use.

column1: * Key Features of the Invention

column1: * Applications and Advantages

* Ensures high tensile strength and durability, even under intensive use.
* Can be used as electric conductors if made with appropriate strand materials.
* Offers improved process economy with high production speeds and precise control over product quality.

* The invention relates to a thread tension control system in a spool creel with multiple spool holders, each equipped with a brake rotor and an adjustable braking element.

column2: * This lever can change its angular position to maintain desired thread tension.

column1: * The invention incorporates a fluid pressure-sensitive biasing arrangement to further influence the tensioning lever.

column2: * This arrangement allows for centralized control of thread tension across all spool holders.

column1: * The preferred embodiment uses a piston/cylinder assembly as the biasing arrangement, enhancing movement compatibility with the tensioning lever.

column2: * This setup prevents contamination and simplifies connection to a pneumatic pressure source.

column1: * The system can rapidly increase braking force upon machine shutdown through higher fluid pressure application to a brake shoe.

column2: * This feature ensures quick response and prevents thread slippage or damage.

column1: * An alternative embodiment replaces the mechanical brake with an electromagnetic brake, which adjusts braking force by covering more or less of a brake disc.

column2: * This modification allows for precise control over braking force and thread tension by altering the coverage of the brake disc.

column2: • Relates to a sewing machine detector for detecting needle position and machine speed.

column1: • Problems with Conventional Detectors:

column2: • Conventional systems suffer from issues like static noise, vibration, and misalignment affecting performance.
• Reflective discs in conventional detectors are costly and complex to manufacture.

column1: • Innovations and Improvements in the New Detector:

column2: • Utilizes flat, light shielding discs which are simpler and cheaper to produce, reducing manufacturing costs.

• Enhances durability and stability of the detection system, even in environments with high vibration.
• Includes a power indicating system using optical fibers, avoiding electromagnetic interference from external sources.

column2: The invention pertains to a load-limiting device for dynamic load-resistant building equipment, specifically designed to dissipate energy and limit damage during dynamic events like earthquakes.

column3: The device is integrated into the building's braced frame structure.
It is capable of undergoing plastic deformation to absorb and dissipate energy, preventing extensive damage to the structure.
Post-event, the device can be easily replaced if it has undergone plastic deformation.

column2: Prior art and existing technologies have various shortcomings in effectively managing dynamic loads without extensive damage or high repair costs.

column3: Traditional systems like concrete shear walls and moment-resistant frames either suffer extensive damage or require costly repairs after dynamic events.
Hydraulic dampers, while controlling energy dissipation, pose challenges in terms of integration, maintenance, and cost.
U.S. Pat. No. 6,651,395 discusses an energy-absorbing device but relies heavily on the precise shape of its components.

column2: The proposed invention offers several improvements and variations over existing technologies.

column3: It provides a method for energy dissipation that limits the load transmitted to critical parts of the structure, thus preserving the integrity of the building.
The device is designed to be easily removable and replaceable, facilitating quick restoration of the frame's integrity post-event.
It accommodates various structural applications and configurations, enhancing its utility across different types of buildings and dynamic load scenarios.

* Overview of Mechanically Stabilized Earth (MSE) Structures

column2: * MSE structures use horizontally positioned soil inclusions and a facing element.
* Applications include retaining walls, bridge abutments, dams, seawalls, and dikes.
* Basic construction involves layering backfill and soil reinforcing elements to desired height.

column1: * Description of Soil Reinforcing Elements and Splicing Needs

column2: * Typical soil reinforcing elements consist of welded wire grids with longitudinal and transverse wires.
* Longitudinal wires may extend into the backfill, but single elements often cannot reach required lengths.
* A system and method for splicing soil reinforcing elements to extend their length are necessary.

column1: * Splicing System and Composite Soil Reinforcing Element

column2: * The splice includes wave plates with protrusions for seating transverse wires and perforations for connective devices.
* A composite soil reinforcing element is created by coupling a soil reinforcing element with a grid-strip using the splice.
* Multiple splices and grid-strips can be used to extend a soil reinforcing element to the required length.

column2: This document discusses an international PCT patent application related to fluid pressure measurement in geological formations.

column3: The application claims priority to an earlier Australian provisional patent application.
It focuses on techniques for measuring fluid pressures at specific depths without interference from other levels.
The techniques are particularly relevant to industries like civil engineering, hydrogeology, and petroleum engineering.

column2: Several developments in pressure measurement technology are detailed, including the use of piezometers and pressure transducers.

column3: Traditional methods involved standpipes with significant limitations due to their volume and connection requirements.
Pneumatic and vibrating wire transducers were developed to address these issues, offering more stability and lower volume requirements.
Recent advancements allow direct cementing of transducers into boreholes, improving direct measurement capabilities.

column2: The document outlines a new method for installing pressure sensors in boreholes using a cement grout.

column3: A conduit with a filter is cemented into the borehole, and fluid is used to clear and then displace the cement around the filter.
This process ensures that the sensor measures fluid pressure at the desired depth without interference from other formation pressures.
The method includes stages of fluid injection to maintain accurate pressure readings and potentially involves hydrofracturing to enhance connectivity.

column2: Detailed descriptions of the installation process and the components involved are provided.

column3: The process involves placing a pressure sensor, a check valve, and a filter into a borehole.
Cement grouting and fluid injections are used to set and clear the installation site.
The system is designed to isolate the sensor from pressures not relevant to the desired measurement depth.

column2: Alternative embodiments and methods are also discussed for different monitoring needs.

column3: One alternative involves a removable pressure transducer that can be periodically calibrated or maintained.
Another method uses a non-return valve to prevent unwanted fluid movement during the cementing process.
These alternatives provide flexibility in monitoring and maintaining the pressure sensing systems.

column2: The document concludes with the benefits of the new pressure sensing systems and methods.

column3: They offer more accurate and isolated measurements of formation pressures.
The systems are adaptable to various geological and operational conditions.
The advancements represent significant improvements over traditional pressure measurement techniques in geological applications.

* The invention relates to a jointing structure with an expansion function for vehicle traveling paths, useful in transit systems and bridges.

column2: * It addresses issues like tire fall-in and stuck-in situations by using a joint block system.

column1: * The jointing structure includes steps with elastic members and a joint block across an expansion gap.

column2: * This design allows for smooth vehicle travel and easy maintenance.

column1: * The joint block and supporting blocks are made of concrete or fiber-reinforced concrete for durability and slip resistance.

column2: * These materials help prevent differences in level at the joints, enhancing safety.

column1: * The elastic members are designed to deform horizontally rather than vertically, aiding in the absorption of bridge expansions or contractions.

column2: * This feature helps maintain the integrity of the traveling path during temperature changes or other environmental effects.

column1: * The invention also includes a method for mounting the elastic members, ensuring they are free from deformation under normal temperature conditions.

column2: * This method simplifies the installation process and reduces the need for adjustments based on temperature predictions.

column1: * The design allows for the decentralization of the expansion gap into smaller gaps, reducing the risk of tire issues and improving ride quality.

column2: * This is achieved by using intermediate joint blocks to divide the expansion gap.

* The invention relates to a floor transport system for fluid treatment chambers used in meat product chilling.

column2: * Designed to prevent contamination of the treatment fluid by the wheels of hand trucks.
* Allows for the sanitary processing of meat products, crucial for compliance with health standards.

column1: * Traditional air chilling methods cause dehydration and slow cooling, leading to product quality issues.

column2: * Evaporation of meat juices during air chilling leads to dehydration and shrinkage.
* Difficulty in removing cellulose casing from products like sausages and frankfurters.

column1: * Recent methods use a chilled brine solution for quicker and more efficient cooling.

column2: * Brine solution is recirculated after cooling the meat, making the process economically advantageous.
* Fluid treatment chambers require a sanitary environment to ensure the quality and safety of the meat.

column1: * The invention includes an enclosed floor track system that keeps truck wheels from contaminating the brine solution.

column2: * Features a wheel channel that prevents the showered fluid or floor fluid from reaching the wheels.
* Includes designs for easy cleaning and maintenance, such as hinged cover plates and inflatable seals.

column1: * The system is adaptable for various types of transport vehicles beyond just wheeled hand trucks.

column2: * Can be used in different industrial applications, not limited to meat product chilling.
* Enhances the recovery and reuse of brine solution, conserving resources and reducing operational costs.

column1: * Detailed descriptions and embodiments are provided in the attached drawings.

column2: * Drawings illustrate the components and assembly of the enclosed floor track system.
* Show how the system prevents fluid contamination and facilitates the transport of meat-laden hand trucks.

• The invention relates to downhole vibratory tools designed to dislodge stuck objects (fish) in wellbores.

column2: • These tools allow for wireline or other tools to pass through them, enhancing utility and access.

column2: The invention relates to a precast concrete retaining wall system designed for easy assembly and robust performance, particularly suitable for use alongside highways and railways.

column3: The system includes a precast concrete face panel with integral counterforts and a solid base, which are manufactured off-site and assembled on-site.
Counterforts extend from the rear of the face panel, enhancing the wall's stability by distributing the load and providing effective resistance against overturning moments.
Temporary shoring is not required during installation, as the components are designed to be self-supporting once assembled.
The design allows for customization in terms of dimensions and aesthetics, making it adaptable to various project requirements.

column2: Several innovative features and methods are incorporated to improve the practicality and efficiency of the retaining wall system.

column3: Reinforcement bars (rebars) within the counterforts and base enhance the structural integrity and facilitate connections between components.
Shear keys and grout are used to securely connect the face panel and base, ensuring a stable and durable assembly.
Provisions for drainage are integrated into the design to manage hydrostatic pressures and maintain the wall's stability.
Options for additional stability include the use of H-piles for poor soil conditions and the potential integration of a vehicle impact barrier on or behind the wall.

column2: The invention pertains to an improved down hole heating system for oil and gas wells to enhance flow by addressing viscosity and paraffin blockages.

Potentially beneficial for deep gas wells with specific occlusion problems like iron sulfide.

column1: * The invention simplifies the process of disconnecting the tool from objects when pulling is not possible.

column2: * This feature prevents the tool from becoming stuck, reducing the risk and cost of operations.

column1: * The tool's operation does not require jarring or violent movements, which protects the well's structural integrity.

column2: * Controlled movements reduce the risk of damaging the well or the tool.

column2: The document details a continuation-in-part of a U.S. patent application related to a new type of collated nail strip for use in fastener driving tools, focusing on a plastic collation system that minimizes debris and enhances nail penetration.

column3: The collation system uses a plastic material molded onto the nails, which adheres to the nail shanks and remains attached as the nail is driven into the substrate, reducing debris.
The plastic material is described as an adhesive polymer, potentially a blend of polypropylene and maleic anhydride modified polypropylene, which is preheated to improve adhesion.
The collation includes features like a tapered collar to facilitate substrate penetration and a selectively weakened region to control where the nail separates from the strip.
Various configurations of the nail strip are discussed, including different shapes and arrangements of the connecting portions between nails to optimize rigidity and minimize debris.

column2: Experimental results and advantages of the new nail strip design are extensively discussed, demonstrating significant improvements in debris reduction and nail withdrawal strength.

column3: Tests comparing the new design to traditional collations show a dramatic reduction in loose debris, with some configurations eliminating debris entirely.
The enhanced adhesion of the plastic to the nails increases the withdrawal strength significantly, making the nails harder to pull out once driven into a substrate.
Design variations such as the positioning of the collar on the nail shank and the specific shape of the connecting portions are optimized to further reduce debris and improve performance.
The document also explores potential modifications like embossed patterns on the connecting portions and different configurations for coiled nail strips.

* The invention pertains to a cooled flow deflection apparatus for high-temperature fluid-flow machines, such as gas turbines.

column2: * Traditional designs use cast cooling channels and ribs, which have several disadvantages including high material stress and complex manufacturing.
* The invention proposes using separate inserts for the cooling channels and ribs, improving cooling efficiency and reducing production complexity.

column1: * The new design involves inserting separate walls or ribs into pre-formed holders within the blade structure.

column2: * This method allows for easier adjustment and replacement of the cooling system components.
* Inserts can be made from metal or heat-resistant non-metal materials, offering flexibility in materials.

column1: * Significant improvements include reduced thermal stress and material use in transitional regions, and lower overall blade weight.

column2: * These changes lead to decreased centrifugal-force stresses on the blade root and airfoil section.
* Simplified casting processes result in fewer production errors and scrap.

column1: * The invention supports various configurations and secure attachment methods for the inserts.

column2: * Examples include straight or U-shaped separating walls that can be soldered or welded for secure attachment.
* Holders for the inserts are integrally formed as rails within the blade, facilitating easy insertion and secure placement.
