column1: 917,"<summary>
* Meeting Overview

column2: * The meeting involved discussions on various aspects of a remote control project named ""Real Reaction.""
* Participants included the Project Manager, User Interface Designer, Industrial Designer, and Marketing personnel.
* The meeting was held to make decisions on design concepts and to integrate feedback from a master class attended by the Project Manager.
* The discussions were informal and included various interruptions and side conversations.

column1: * Technical Issues and Design Concepts

column2: * User Interface Designer reported issues with a laptop, affecting work progress.
* Industrial Designer presented ideas on materials and design preferences for different age groups.
* Concepts for energy sources for the remote were discussed, including battery, kinetic, and solar options.
* Design options for the remote included different shapes, materials (rubber vs. plastic), and the integration of a touch screen.

column1: * Marketing Insights and Preferences

column2: * Marketing shared insights from trend-watching trips to Paris and Milan, focusing on preferences of different age groups.
* Younger audiences preferred fresh, vibrant colors and soft materials, while older demographics favored traditional styles and materials.
* Marketing suggested customizable covers for the remote, similar to mobile phones, to appeal to younger users.
* The importance of the remote appearing technologically innovative and easy to use was emphasized.

column1: * Feature Discussions

column2: * Various features were debated including the type of control interface (buttons vs. touch screen) and energy sources.
* The possibility of integrating games and parental control features was discussed, with mixed opinions on their necessity and implementation.
* Voice recognition was considered but viewed as potentially problematic due to ambient noise interference.
* Marketing proposed the idea of removable covers for customization and a dual approach to material use, combining hard and soft elements.

column1: * Decision Making and Conclusions

column2: * Decisions were made to combine kinetic and battery energy sources for the remote.
* The group agreed on using rubber for its tactile quality and durability, over plastic.
* It was decided to incorporate both traditional and touch screen controls, depending on cost and technological feasibility.
* The meeting concluded with plans to further refine these ideas and prepare for prototyping.

* Lynne Neagle AM opened the meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee, with no apologies for absence and no declarations of interest.

column2: * Welcomed Kirsty Williams AM, Cabinet Secretary for Education, and her deputies for a session on the Welsh baccalaureate.
* Moved directly to questions after introductions.

column1: * Julie Morgan AM questioned the value of the Welsh baccalaureate, focusing on its reception by learners and teachers.

column2: * Kirsty Williams emphasized the qualification's broad educational scope and its preparation of students for further study and work.
* Acknowledged some concerns about workload and stress related to the Welsh bac, as noted in a review by Qualifications Wales.

column1: * Discussion on how the Welsh bac is valued differently at key stages and its impact on student well-being.

column2: * Kirsty Williams noted variability in student experiences, often influenced by school leadership and teaching quality.
* Emphasized ongoing efforts to ensure consistent and enthusiastic support for the bac across schools.

column1: * Universities' recognition of the Welsh bac discussed, particularly in relation to admission processes.

column2: * Kirsty Williams provided evidence of the qualification's acceptance and value in higher education, including adjustments in university offers.
* Addressed concerns about inconsistencies in university recognition, affirming the qualification's equivalence to A-levels.

column1: * The committee explored the universal adoption of the Welsh bac and its implications.

column2: * Kirsty Williams advocated for it to be the norm, with flexibility for individual student needs.
* Emphasized the importance of professional learning for teachers to effectively deliver the Welsh bac.

column1: * Concerns about the impact of the Welsh bac on other curriculum subjects and student choices.

column2: * Kirsty Williams refuted the idea that the Welsh bac narrows the curriculum, suggesting it broadens learning opportunities.
* Addressed anecdotal evidence of students avoiding the Welsh bac by choosing education institutions outside Wales.

923,"<summary>
• Lynne Neagle AM opened the session, welcoming members and guests to discuss the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill.

column2: • Apologies from Jack Sargeant were noted, and Vikki Howells was welcomed as his substitute.
• Declarations of interest were requested from members, with none declared.

column1: • Janet Finch-Saunders AM raised concerns about public opposition to the bill, citing a consultation showing 70% of personal respondents against the bill.

column2: • She highlighted the distinction made by some parents between child abuse and light physical punishment.
• Julie Morgan AM responded, emphasizing the bill's aim to protect children's rights by prohibiting all physical punishment.

column1: • Julie Morgan AM argued that the bill addresses the protection of children under human rights, referencing the United Nations Committee on the Rights of the Child.

column2: • She stressed that any form of physical punishment, however minor, is seen as incompatible with children's human rights.
• Morgan also discussed the confusion caused by legal defenses for physical punishment, advocating for clearer laws.

column1: • Janet Finch-Saunders AM questioned the potential increase in child-on-child violence, referencing statistics from Sweden.

column2: • Julie Morgan AM acknowledged mixed evidence but cited a study of 88 countries showing reduced youth violence in countries that prohibit corporal punishment.

column1: • Concerns about increased social services workload were discussed, with Julie Morgan AM reassuring that the bill aligns with existing child protection frameworks.

column2: • She mentioned ongoing preparations and an implementation group to address practical implications and support from various agencies.

column1: • Suzy Davies AM expressed concerns about the timing and necessity of the bill, questioning the readiness of implementation strategies.

column2: • Julie Morgan AM assured that extensive preparations and consultations have been made, emphasizing the importance of legislative clarity.

column1: • The discussion also touched on the potential impacts on social services and the police, with assurances of manageable adjustments and no significant negative impacts anticipated.

column2: • Julie Morgan AM highlighted the importance of an awareness campaign to accompany the legislation, ensuring public understanding and support.

column1: • The session concluded with discussions on various aspects of implementation, including training for professionals, data collection, and monitoring the bill's impact.

column2: • Overall, the committee explored both support and concerns for the bill, with detailed responses from Julie Morgan AM addressing specific queries and emphasizing the bill's focus on children's rights and welfare.

column1: * Team Introduction and Icebreaker Activity

column1: * Discussion on Remote Control Design and Features

column2: * Marketing expressed concerns about the complexity of current remote controls and multimedia overload.

* Ideas were proposed for a remote with main functions and possibly another for more specialized functions.

column1: * Project Financials and Next Steps

column2: * The target selling price for the remote is set at 25 Euros with a production cost goal of 12.50 Euros.
* The team aims for a profit of 15 million Euros, targeting an international market.
* Next steps include further individual work on design aspects and another meeting to consolidate ideas and progress.

column2: The team discussed the final design of a banana-themed remote control.

column3: The remote features ergonomic design with scroll wheels for volume and channel control.
It includes a turbo button for quick channel surfing and doubles as a power button.
The base station is designed with a banana leaf aesthetic and functions as a charging station and locator.

column2: Marketing raised concerns about the multifunctionality of buttons and their ease of use.

column3: There was confusion about the teletext button and its interaction with the scroll wheels.
Marketing questioned the practicality of navigating to specific teletext pages.
The team clarified that the scroll wheels would change functions based on mode (teletext or normal).

column2: The remote's power source includes solar cells and rechargeable batteries, though the necessity of solar cells was questioned.

column3: The team discussed the placement and necessity of solar cells given the presence of a charging base.
There was a consensus that the solar cells might be redundant.
The remote's battery life was estimated to be extensive due to intermittent use.

column2: Cost evaluation and materials were a significant part of the discussion.

column3: The team aimed to keep production costs under €12.5.
Choices of materials and technology (like opting for a regular chip) were made to control costs.
The possibility of using rubber for durability was discussed but considered too expensive.

column2: User Interface and Industrial Design highlighted the remote's innovative features.

column3: The remote's ergonomic design and intuitive button placement were noted.
The base station's dual functionality and aesthetic appeal were emphasized.
The antenna functionality integrated into the leaf design was considered a clever addition.

column2: There were mixed opinions on the market viability and overall appeal of the remote.

column3: The design was seen as trendy and potentially appealing to a younger, style-conscious demographic.
Concerns were raised about the practicality and appeal of a banana-shaped remote in a typical home setting.
The team acknowledged the need for further market research and possibly reevaluating the design.

column2: The meeting concluded with plans to refine the prototype and conduct more focused market research.

• Lynne Neagle AM opened the committee meeting, welcoming members and guests.

column1: • Discussion on school improvement and raising standards began with Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education.

column2: • Kirsty Williams highlighted the ongoing involvement of the OECD in reviewing Welsh education.
• A new OECD report on Welsh education was anticipated for publication in March.

column1: • Kirsty Williams discussed the use of powers under the School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2013.

column2: • Local authorities have powers of intervention in schools, which have been used variably across Wales.
• Successful interventions in schools like Flintshire and Torfaen were highlighted.

column1: • The national evaluation and improvement resource was discussed as a significant tool for raising school standards.

column2: • Emphasis was placed on self-evaluation and the development of a robust approach to it.
• The resource was being tested and evaluated for effectiveness.

column1: • Concerns about schools needing urgent improvement were addressed.

column2: • A new multi-agency approach was being piloted to support schools causing concern.
• The approach includes collaboration between schools, local authorities, regional consortia, Estyn, and Welsh Government.

column1: • The role of regional consortia in school improvement was examined.

column2: • Questions were raised about the consistency and effectiveness of the four consortia.

column1: • The use of performance measures to evaluate school success was debated.

column2: • Changes to performance measures were made to avoid narrow focuses and promote broader educational goals.
• The interim measures are under review, aligning with curriculum changes and broader educational reforms.

column1: • The challenge of closing the attainment gap for pupils eligible for free school meals was acknowledged.

column2: • Despite significant investment through the pupil development grant, disparities persist, necessitating ongoing efforts and adjustments.

column2: The episode begins with Booth, Brennan, and Sweets in a therapy session.

column3: Sweets tries to conduct a team-building exercise.
Booth is skeptical and resistant to the therapy.

The session is interrupted by a call about a new case.

column2: Booth and Brennan are called to a crime scene where they find a cooked body.

column3: The body is discovered by teenagers at an abandoned VA hospital.
Initial assessments suggest the body had been exposed to high temperatures.
Forensic analysis at the lab suggests a possible connection to another case involving cannibalism.
The victim is identified as Franklin Curtis, an organic supermarket chain founder.

column2: Investigations reveal Curtis had many enemies due to his aggressive business tactics.

column3: Booth and Brennan interview Curtis's family and learn about his pushy nature in business.
They also discover Curtis had been trying to convert local farmers to organic farming, often by force.
Suspicions arise around a local farmer who had a motive to harm Curtis.

column2: The investigation leads Booth and Brennan to a composting facility.

column3: They learn that the facility is used by local organic farmers, including Curtis.
Another body is found in the compost, identified as a young woman.
Forensic evidence links the compost facility to the crime.
The team uncovers that the woman was Curtis's daughter from a previous relationship.

column2: The case concludes with the arrest of Charlie Rogan, initially suspected of both murders.

column3: However, further evidence reveals that Curtis's other daughter, Kat, accidentally killed her half-sister.
Kat was trying to confront her about their father's infidelity.
Charlie only tried to cover up the accident to protect Kat.
The episode ends with Booth and Brennan reflecting on the emotional complexities of their job.
